# ZeroNet

**ZeroNet** is a [[decentralized]] network of [[peer-to-peer]] users. It is built in [[Python]] and fully [[open source]]. Sites have specific addresses which can be accessed through a browser when using its client. ZeroNet is not [[anonymous]] by default, but users can hide their IP address by using the built-in [[Tor]] functionality. ZeroNet uses elliptic curve [[cryptography]] and the [[BitTorrent]] network.

Users can publish static or dynamic websites into ZeroNet and visitors automatically serve the visited website from their computer, with the option to stop serving the website at any time by either pausing or deleting it. Sites will remain online even if it is being served by only one [[peer-to-peer|peer]].

When changes are published by the site owner, connected [[nodes]] serving that site (previous visitors) will receive the updates done to the site's content.

ZeroNet comes with a built-in [[SQL]] [[database]]. This makes content-heavy site development easy. The [[database]] is also synced with hosting [[nodes]].

The existence of [[peer-to-peer]] online [[website|websites]] had been hypothesized for some time, with [[The Pirate Bay]] suggesting they would build such network, as well as [[BitTorrent Inc.]] which created the closed source [[Project Maelstrom]]. One other similar project is [[MaidSafe]], though it has not yet seen widespread use, and has been said to focus more on file storage.

# The New ZeroWiki

This is a clone of [[ZeroWiki]] created with better organization and information-richness in mind.
[[ZeroWiki]] is a wiki platform for [[ZeroNet]], the distributed web network based on [[BitTorrent]], [[Bitcoin]] and [[Tor]]. 

[[ZeroWiki]] is public and [[cloning|clonable]]. Wikis can be used for taking notes, storing snippets, sharing knowledge by creating [[FAQ]]s and documentations, keeping track of your goals, or as simple to-do lists. See the [[help|help page]] for a more in-depth view of how it works.

If you want to contribute to the wiki, go to the [[Contributing to this Wiki]] page for guidelines. If you don't know where to categorize a page, link to the page from the [[Uncategorized Pages]] page. You can use the [[Sandbox]] page to test out editing ZeroWiki pages.

# Decentralized | [[Internet]]

A decentralized network is a network where there is no centralized point of access (unlike traditional networks with clients and servers) and therefore no single point of failure. In a decentralized network, files are distributed by multiple users, rather than solely the owner of those files.

**ZeroWiki supports basic markdown tags, below is a collection of helpful tags to help visitors create articles with style.**

---

Paragraphs are separated
by a blank line.

Two spaces at the end of a line leave a  
line break.

---

Horizontal Lines  like this can be done with \***, \--- and \___

An internal link like [[ZeroWiki:Sandbox]].

This is [an example] [id] reference-[style] link.

        [id]: http://example1.com/  "Optional Title1 Here"

       ----

 ## This Is H2

---

Text attributes:  

| Markdown           | Normal          |  
| ------------- |:-------------:|  
|.................... |......................|  
| _italic_  | \_Italic_  |  
|.................... |......................| 
| **bold**  | \*\*Bold**  |  
|.................... |......................|  
| `monospace` | \`Monospace` |  
|.................... |......................|  
â€‹

---

### How to make a list:  
notice the two spaces before *pears* and *oranges*. They will make it a sub-list.  

```
Numbered list:  

  1. apples
  2. oranges
    * pears  
  3. banana
```
```
 Bullet list:

  * apples 
    1. oranges
  * pears
  * banana
```

Numbered list:  
1. apples
2. oranges
  * pears  
3. banana

Bullet list:  
  * apples     
    1. oranges
  * banana                   
  * pears                       
â€‹
---
### To make a code snippet:  

| Markdown           | Normal          |  
| ---------------------------- |:----------------------------:|  
|.................................................. |....................................................|  
| ``` The code you want to see ```  |     \`\`\` The code you want to see \`\`\`   
â€‹

---
### Making a table:  
```
| Markdown           | Normal             |  
| ------------------ |:------------------:|  
|................... |....................|  
|* markymark *       | â€‹nonormal           |  
```  
| Markdown           | Normal                    |  
| ----------------------- |:-----------------------:|  
|....................... |.........................|  
| ** markymark **         | â€‹nonormal               |  
â€‹

---
### Escaping a markdown character:  
As an escape char you can use "\" before the char you want to escape. This will make it read as a normal character and not hold any special meaning. Good if you want to write a \* for instance.

| Markdown           | Normal          
| ------------- |:-------------:|  
|.............................. |................................|  
| \*literal asterisks\*  | â€‹\\\* literal asterisksâ€‹\â€‹*  |  
â€‹

---
Further reading can be done at [GitHub's Markdown-Cheatsheet](https://github.com/adam-p/markdown-here/wiki/Markdown-Cheatsheet)

# Wikis | [[Zite Categories]]

A **wiki** is a type of website in which users can edit and contribute to its content. Examples of wikis include Wikipedia, Wiktionary, ZeroWiki and the Debian Wiki. The word 'wiki' comes from Hawaiian, meaning fast or quickly. Wikis are increasingly popular with community groups and small organizations, and are recognized as a type of 'Web 2.0' site.

Most wiki's are typically a collection of information on a specific subject such as Linux or many different subjects such as everything from Pizza to The origin of the Internet.

* [Original ZeroWiki](http://127.0.0.1:43110/138R53t3ZW7KDfSfxVpWUsMXgwUnsDNXLP)
* [ZeroTuto](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Jtjb5CU9aod4jtz8hF5NPPqFKofRSsb4x/)

# Kaffiene | [[Search Engine]]

[Kaffiene](/kaffiene.bit) is a [[search engine]] developed by [[Kaffie]] for [[ZeroNet]] [[zite|zites]]. It uses naive and [[regex]] queries to search through a plain-text index of sites along with hand-picked tags. The site freely shares its index and is [[cloneable]]. There are currently over 1185 sites listed in the index.

In April 23, 2017, Kaffiene [has become open-source](/zeronews.bit/?Post:4:Kaffiene+is+now+open-source).

# Zite | [[ZeroNet]]

A Zite is a [[ZeroNet]] [[website]]. Zites have the notable difference of being entirely [[decentralized]] and work even if the visitor is offline. Zites are designed to be entirely [[open source]] and freely shared. Zite owners can also make their site [[cloning|cloneable]]. This ensures content is not censored and cannot be forcefully taken down.

However, due to how the site is distributed and viewed, sites must be entirely contained within local [[HTML]] and [[JavaScript]] files. Information for the site can be stored in an [[SQLite]] database or in [[JSON]] files.

Zites require the private key generated with the address in order to be edited or published. Users of the zite have a subdirectory they may edit within the zite's file structure.

[ZeroTuto](/1Jtjb5CU9aod4jtz8hF5NPPqFKofRSsb4x), is a great resource for creating zites.

Various attempts have been made to index and search the hundreds of zites that have been created. [[Search engine|Search engines]] like [[Kaffiene]] or [[ZeroSearch]] allow searching through hand-crafted indexes using key terms. While other zites, like [[0list]] or [[ZeroCentral]], allow user submissions to generate a list.

# ZeroNet

**ZeroNet** is a [[decentralized]] network of [[peer-to-peer]] users. It is built in [[Python]] and fully [[open source]]. Sites have specific addresses which can be accessed through a browser when using its client. ZeroNet is not [[anonymous]] by default, but users can hide their IP address by using the built-in [[Tor]] functionality. ZeroNet uses elliptic curve [[cryptography]] and the [[BitTorrent]] network.

Users can publish static or dynamic websites into ZeroNet and visitors automatically serve the visited website from their computer, with the option to stop serving the website at any time by either pausing or deleting it. Sites will remain online even if it is being served by only one [[peer-to-peer|peer]].

When changes are published by the site owner, connected [[nodes]] serving that site (previous visitors) will receive the updates done to the site's content.

ZeroNet comes with a built-in [[SQL]] [[database]]. This makes content-heavy site development easy. The [[database]] is also synced with hosting [[nodes]].

The existence of [[peer-to-peer]] online [[website|websites]] had been hypothesized for some time, with [[The Pirate Bay]] suggesting they would build such network, as well as [[BitTorrent Inc.]] which created the closed source [[Project Maelstrom]]. One other similar project is [[MaidSafe]], though it has not yet seen widespread use, and has been said to focus more on file storage.

# Zite | [[ZeroNet]]

A Zite is a [[ZeroNet]] [[website]]. Zites have the notable difference of being entirely [[decentralized]] and work even if the visitor is offline. Zites are designed to be entirely [[open source]] and freely shared. Zite owners can also make their site [[cloning|cloneable]]. This ensures content is not censored and cannot be forcefully taken down.

However, due to how the site is distributed and viewed, sites must be entirely contained within local [[HTML]] and [[JavaScript]] files. Information for the site can be stored in an [[SQLite]] database or in [[JSON]] files.

Zites require the private key generated with the address in order to be edited or published. Users of the zite have a subdirectory they may edit within the zite's file structure.

[KEEP THIS?]
[ZeroTuto](/1Jtjb5CU9aod4jtz8hF5NPPqFKofRSsb4x), is a great resource for creating zites.

Various attempts have been made to index and search the hundreds of zites that have been created. [[Search engine|Search engines]] like [[Kaffiene]] or [[ZeroSearch]] allow searching through hand-crafted indexes using key terms. While other zites, like [[0list]] or [[ZeroCentral]], allow user submissions to generate a list.

# Contributing To This Wiki

In order to make sure the navigation remains consistent, follow the below guidelines on where to link new pages:

1. Select a main, general topic -
    * These general topics are listed on the homepage. They include: [[ZeroNet]], [[Internet]], [[Cryptography]], and [[Programming]]
    * As a general rule, if something is different enough to not fall within one of these topics, then make a new topic.
    * Another general rule, if it needs to be further subdivided into categories, then *chances are* it should be a topic.
2. Categories/Groups (if applicable) -
    * These categories/groups further divide the general topics. For example, the [[ZeroNet]] topic has these subtopics: [[Zites]], [[ZeroNet Plugins]], and [[Well-Known Developers]].
    * However, not everything listed in a topic must be a category or group. You can have pages that don't have pages below it in the hierarchy.
    * If something doesn't fall within one of the current categories, create a new category.
3. If you are creating a new Category/Group or a new page within in a Category/Group, do the following:
    * Make sure you are adding the title of the page or category/group at the top using a heading (`# `).
    * Please put a vertical bar with a link to the Category/Group or Topic after the title for pages inside of a category or categories/groups.
4. Other Guidelines
    * All other heading on a page should be sub-headings, starting with `## `
    * When linking to zites, be sure to remove `http://127.0.0.1:43110` at the beginning (but retain the `/` at the start).
    * Only Topics on the homepage are allowed to put some of the subpages below them. The amount of subpages should be limited to the top 5-6 pages that would be most useful on the homepage. Be sure to add a `See More` link if more subpages exist within the topic page.
5. You can link to related pages by putting them under a `See Also` heading.

*It should be noted that currently this Wiki only deals with technology topics. In the future, I may rename topics to sub-topics and create new topics that are more general and cover other areas, like Politics, Art, etc.*

# Optional Files | [[ZeroNet Functionality]]

**Optional files** is a feature of [[ZeroNet]] that allows [[peer-to-peer|peers]] to only download requested files. A site could make each page optional so that only when requested (going to the page) it would be downloaded, and then served to whomever requests it later.

Another technique is to download all pages by default and only download images, videos or software when they are requested.

To implement optional files, one needs to add the following structure to their [[content.json]]:

```
"optional": "(folder/|anotherfolder/|file|anotherfile)",
```

## BitTorrent

**BitTorrent** is a communications protocol of [[peer-to-peer]] file sharing which is used to distribute data over the Internet. BitTorrent is one of the most common protocols for transferring large files, and peer-to-peer networks have been estimated to collectively account for approximately 43% to 70% of all Internet traffic (depending on location) as of February 2009. 

To send or receive files one uses a BitTorrent client; a computer program that implements the BitTorrent protocol. Such clients include Transmission, qBittorrent, Vuze, Deluge, and BitComet. BitTorrent trackers provide a list of files available for transfer, and allow the client to find peers known as seeds who may transfer the files.

# Python | [[Programming Languages]]

Python is a widely used general-purpose, high-level programming language. Its design philosophy emphasizes code readability, and its syntax allows programmers to express concepts in fewer lines of code than would be possible in languages such as C++ or Java.

## Who created Python?

Python was conceived in the late 1980s and its implementation was started in December 1989 by Guido van Rossum at CWI in the Netherlands as a successor to the ABC language (itself inspired by SETL) capable of exception handling and interfacing with the Amoeba operating system.

## What is Python 2.7?

Python is a programming language. It's used for many different applications. It's used in some high schools and colleges as an introductory programming language because Python is easy to learn, but it's also used by professional software developers at places such as Google, NASA, and Lucasfilm Ltd.

# ZeroNet Releases | [[ZeroNet]]

## 0.6.0
*October 17, 2017*

### Fixed
* Sub-directories in user directories

### Added
* New Plugin: [[Big Files]]
* Automatic pinning on Big file download
* Enable TCP_NODELAY for supporting sockets
* actionOptionalFileList API command arguments to list non-downloaded files or only big files
* serverShowDirectory API command arguments to allow to display site's directory in OS file browser
* fileNeed API command to initialize optional file downloading
* wrapperGetAjaxKey API command to request nonce for AJAX request
* Json.gz support for database files
* P2P port checking
* --download_optional auto argument to enable automatic optional file downloading for newly added site
* Statistics for big files and protocol command requests on /Stats
* Allow to set user limitation based on auth_address

### Changed
* More aggressive and frequent connection timeout checking
* Use out of msgpack context file streaming for files larger than 512KB
* Allow optional files workers over the worker limit
* Automatic redirection to wrapper on nonce_error
* Send websocket event on optional file deletion
* Optimize sites.json saving
* Enable faster C-based msgpack packer by default
* Major optimization on Bootstrapper plugin SQL queries
* Don't reset bad file counter on restart, to allow easier give up on unreachable files
* Incoming connection limit changed from 1000 to 500 to avoid reaching socket limit on Windows
* Changed tracker boot.zeronet.io domain, because zeronet.io got banned in some countries

## 0.5.7
*July 27, 2017*

### Fixed
* Detecting data directory when running Windows distribution exe
* OpenSSL loading under Android 6+
* Error on exiting when no connection server started

### Added
* New Plugin: [[CORS Plugin]] to request read permission to other site's content
* New API command: userSetSettings/userGetSettings to store site's settings in users.json
* Avoid file download if the file size does not match with the requested one
* Javascript and wrapper less file accessing using /raw/ prefix
* --silent command line option to disable logging to stdout

### Changed
* Better error reporting on sign/verification errors
* More test for sign and verification process
* Update to OpenSSL v1.0.21
* Limit compressed files to 6MB to avoid zip/tar.gz bomb
* Allow space, [], () characters in filenames
* Disable cross-site resource loading to improve privacy
* Download directly accessed Pdf/Svg/Swf files instead of displaying them to avoid wrapper escape using in JS in SVG file.
* Disallow potentially unsafe regular expressions to avoid ReDoS

* Opened port checking

* CoffeeScript 1.12.6 compatibility
* Multi value argument parsing
* Database error when running from directory that contains special characters
* Site lock violation logging

* More compact list formatting in json

* Improved Spanish translation

# Peer-to-Peer | [[Internet]]

**Peer-to-peer** (**P2P**) computing or networking is a distributed application architecture that partitions tasks or work loads between peers. Peers are equally privileged participants in the application. They are said to form a peer-to-peer network of [[nodes]].

Peers make a portion of their resources, such as processing power, disk storage or network bandwidth, directly available to other network participants, without the need for central coordination by servers or stable hosts. Peers are both suppliers and consumers of resources, in contrast to the traditional client-server model in which the consumption and supply of resources is divided.

# Blockchain | [[Cryptography]]

A **block chain** or **blockchain** is a distributed database based on the [[Bitcoin]] protocol that maintains a continuously growing list of data records hardened against tampering and revision, even by its operators. 
The initial and most widely known application of block chain technology is the public ledger of transactions for Bitcoin.

* [[Cryptocurrency]]

# Cryptocurrency | [[Cryptography]]

**Cryptocurrency** (plural: cryptocurrencies) is a form of money that is created and traded through anonymous digital networks. The funds are stored in wallets that are identified by a [[UUID]], and are encrypted with various encryption algorithms. Transactions are typically recorded by public network [[nodes]] and then distributed via [[peer-to-peer]] downloads in a ledger known as a [[blockchain]].

**[[Bitcoin]]** is commonly referred to as the first cryptocurrency, although others existed before it. It was the first successful decentralized currency system, and the first to be widely publicized and used. 

Since Bitcoin's success, many other cryptocurrencies have been created with similar systems, such as [[Litecoin]], [[Dogecoin]], [[Namecoin]], and countless others. 

* [[Bitcoin]]

# Bitcoin | [[Cryptocurrency]]

**Bitcoin** is a digital asset and a payment system invented by [[Satoshi Nakamoto]], who published the invention in 2008 and released it as [[open-source]] software in 2009. The system is [[peer-to-peer]]; users can transact directly without an intermediary. Transactions are verified by network [[nodes]] and recorded in a public distributed ledger called the [[blockchain]]. 

The ledger uses bitcoin as its unit of account. The system works without a central repository or single administrator, which has led the U.S. Treasury to categorize bitcoin as a decentralized virtual currency. Bitcoin is often called the first [[cryptocurrency]], although prior systems existed. Bitcoin is more correctly described as the first decentralized digital currency. It is the largest of its kind in terms of total market value.

# Website | [[World Wide Web]]

A website, also written as web site, is a collection of related web pages, including multimedia content, typically identified with a common domain name, and published on at least one web server. A web site may be accessible via a public Internet Protocol ([[IP]]) network, such as the Internet, or a private local area network ([[LAN]]), by referencing a uniform resource locator ([[URL]]) that identifies the site. All publicly accessible websites collectively constitute the [[World Wide Web]], while private websites are typically a part of an [[intranet]].

Web pages, which are the building blocks of websites, are documents, typically composed in plain text interspersed with formatting instructions of Hypertext Markup Language ([[HTML]], [[XHTML]]). They may incorporate elements from other websites with suitable markup anchors. Web pages are accessed and transported with the Hypertext Transfer Protocol ([[HTTP]]), which may optionally employ encryption ([[HTTP]] Secure, [[HTTPS]]) to provide security and privacy for the user. The user's application, often a web browser, renders the page content according to its [[HTML]] markup instructions onto a display terminal.

[[Hyperlinking]] between web pages conveys to the reader the site structure and guides the navigation of the site, which often starts with a home page containing a directory of the site web content. Some websites require user registration or subscription to access content. Examples of subscription websites include many business sites, parts of news websites, academic journal websites, gaming websites, file-sharing websites, message boards, web-based email, social networking websites, websites providing real-time stock market data, as well as sites providing various other services.

# World Wide Web | [[Internet]]

An information system on the [[Internet]] that allows documents to be connected to other documents by hypertext links, enabling the user to search for information by moving from one document to another.

* [[Website]]

# Contributing To This Wiki

In order to make sure the navigation remains consistent, follow the below guidelines on where to link new pages:

1. Select a main, general topic -
    * These general topics are listed on the homepage. They include: [[ZeroNet]], [[Internet]], [[Cryptography]], and [[Programming]]
    * As a general rule, if something is different enough to not fall within one of these topics, then make a new topic.
    * Another general rule, if it needs to be further subdivided into categories, then *chances are* it should be a topic.
2. Categories/Groups (if applicable) -
    * These categories/groups further divide the general topics. For example, the [[ZeroNet]] topic has these subtopics: [[Zites]], [[ZeroNet Plugins]], and [[Well-Known Developers]].
    * However, not everything listed in a topic must be a category or group. You can have pages that don't have pages below it in the hierarchy.
    * If something doesn't fall within one of the default subtopics, create a new subtopic. If it isn't further subdivided, then it isn't considered a category; but, you can still put it within the topic.
3. If you are creating a new Category/Group or a new page within in a Category/Group, do the following:
    * Make sure you are adding the title of the page or category/group at the top using a heading (`# `).
    * Please put a vertical bar with a link to the Category/Group or Topic after the title for pages inside of a category or categories/groups.
4. Other Guidelines
    * Categories/Groups should be listed before pages that aren't categories/groups.
    * All other heading on a page should be sub-headings, starting with `## `
    * When linking to zites, be sure to remove `http://127.0.0.1:43110` at the beginning (but retain the `/` at the start).
    * Only Topics on the homepage are allowed to put some of the subpages below them. The amount of subpages should be limited to the top 5-6 pages that would be most useful on the homepage. Be sure to add a `See More` link if more subpages exist within the topic page.
5. You can link to related pages by putting them under a `See Also` heading.

*It should be noted that currently this Wiki only deals with technology topics. In the future, I may rename topics to sub-topics and create new topics that are more general and cover other areas, like Politics, Art, etc.*

# ZeroNet

**ZeroNet** is a [[decentralized]] network of [[peer-to-peer]] users. It is built in [[Python]] and fully [[open source]]. Sites have specific addresses which can be accessed through a browser when using its client. ZeroNet is not [[anonymous]] by default, but users can hide their IP address by using the built-in [[Tor]] functionality. ZeroNet uses elliptic curve [[cryptography]] and the [[BitTorrent]] network.

Users can publish static or dynamic websites into ZeroNet and visitors automatically serve the visited website from their computer, with the option to stop serving the website at any time by either pausing or deleting it. Sites will remain online even if it is being served by only one [[peer-to-peer|peer]].

When changes are published by the site owner, connected [[nodes]] serving that site (previous visitors) will receive the updates done to the site's content.

ZeroNet comes with a built-in [[SQL]] [[database]]. This makes content-heavy site development easy. The [[database]] is also synced with hosting [[nodes]].

The existence of [[peer-to-peer]] online [[website|websites]] had been hypothesized for some time, with [[The Pirate Bay]] suggesting they would build such network, as well as [[BitTorrent Inc.]] which created the closed source [[Project Maelstrom]]. One other similar project is [[MaidSafe]], though it has not yet seen widespread use, and has been said to focus more on file storage.

# Cloning | [[ZeroNet Functionality]]

Cloning is the act of making a clone of a [[Zite]]. 

This can be achieved by going to [[ZeroHello]] ([[ZeroNet]]'s home page, and your home page), hovering over the site you want to clone, clicking on the 3 dots at the right and selecting "`clone`".

Most users get familiar with this when they first clone [ZeroBlog](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Blog.ZeroNetwork.bit), a [[ZeroNet]] powered blog.

## Enable cloning on your [[zite]]

You may have noticed the "`clone`" option is not there for every website. The website owner has to enable this in the site's [[content.json]] by setting the boolean "`cloneable`" to "`true`", then [[signing]] and [[publishing]] it.

## *-default files

Files with `-default` suffix will be copied instead of their equivalent without this suffix. For example, if their are both a `data` and a `data-default` directory in the zite, only the `data-default` will be copied. It's commonly used to avoid having a lot of useless data being copied, like articles in [ZeroBlog](/Blog.ZeroNetwork.bit).

# Tor | [[Internet]]
## What is Tor?

Tor is a service that helps you to protect your anonymity while using the Internet. Tor is comprised of two parts: software you can download that allows you to use the Internet anonymously, and the volunteer network of computers that makes it possible for that software to work.

## Who created the Tor network?

The core principle of Tor, "onion routing", was developed in the mid-1990s by United States Naval Research Laboratory employees, mathematician Paul Syverson and computer scientists Michael Reed and David Goldschlag, with the purpose of protecting U.S. intelligence communications online.

Nowadays the software is maintained by the [Tor Project](https://torproject.org) and has stemmed into several child projects based on it, such as the TorBrowser (for desktop systems) , Orbot (for Android systems) and others.

## Is it illegal to use the Tor Browser?

Using Tor to browse the Internet is not illegal. 
Hiding your IP address and browsing history is not illegal in and of itself. 

However, don't forget that the concept of legality varies according to the laws of a given place. The above is true for the United States, and probably for most of Europe and South America as well, but might be different for your country.

## How do you connect to the Web through the Tor network?

The simplest way is using the Tor Browser Bundle which contains all the required tools. To install it, go to [www.torproject.org](https://www.torproject.org) and download the appropriate file for your operating system. (Check the PGP signature of the downloaded file to verify integrity). Run the downloaded file, choose an extraction location, then open the folder and click Start Tor Browser.  Depending on where you are, you may need use bridges such as obfs4 or meek-google.

# Website | [[Internet]]

A website, also written as web site, is a collection of related web pages, including multimedia content, typically identified with a common domain name, and published on at least one web server. A web site may be accessible via a public Internet Protocol ([[IP]]) network, such as the Internet, or a private local area network ([[LAN]]), by referencing a uniform resource locator ([[URL]]) that identifies the site. All publicly accessible websites collectively constitute the [[World Wide Web]], while private websites are typically a part of an [[intranet]].

Web pages, which are the building blocks of websites, are documents, typically composed in plain text interspersed with formatting instructions of Hypertext Markup Language ([[HTML]], [[XHTML]]). They may incorporate elements from other websites with suitable markup anchors. Web pages are accessed and transported with the Hypertext Transfer Protocol ([[HTTP]]), which may optionally employ encryption ([[HTTP]] Secure, [[HTTPS]]) to provide security and privacy for the user. The user's application, often a web browser, renders the page content according to its [[HTML]] markup instructions onto a display terminal.

[[Hyperlinking]] between web pages conveys to the reader the site structure and guides the navigation of the site, which often starts with a home page containing a directory of the site web content. Some websites require user registration or subscription to access content. Examples of subscription websites include many business sites, parts of news websites, academic journal websites, gaming websites, file-sharing websites, message boards, web-based email, social networking websites, websites providing real-time stock market data, as well as sites providing various other services.

# ZeroNet Releases

## 0.6.0
*October 17, 2017*

### Fixed
* Sub-directories in user directories

### Added
* New Plugin: [[Big Files]]
* Automatic pinning on Big file download
* Enable TCP_NODELAY for supporting sockets
* actionOptionalFileList API command arguments to list non-downloaded files or only big files
* serverShowDirectory API command arguments to allow to display site's directory in OS file browser
* fileNeed API command to initialize optional file downloading
* wrapperGetAjaxKey API command to request nonce for AJAX request
* Json.gz support for database files
* P2P port checking
* --download_optional auto argument to enable automatic optional file downloading for newly added site
* Statistics for big files and protocol command requests on /Stats
* Allow to set user limitation based on auth_address

### Changed
* More aggressive and frequent connection timeout checking
* Use out of msgpack context file streaming for files larger than 512KB
* Allow optional files workers over the worker limit
* Automatic redirection to wrapper on nonce_error
* Send websocket event on optional file deletion
* Optimize sites.json saving
* Enable faster C-based msgpack packer by default
* Major optimization on Bootstrapper plugin SQL queries
* Don't reset bad file counter on restart, to allow easier give up on unreachable files
* Incoming connection limit changed from 1000 to 500 to avoid reaching socket limit on Windows
* Changed tracker boot.zeronet.io domain, because zeronet.io got banned in some countries

## 0.5.7
*July 27, 2017*

### Fixed
* Detecting data directory when running Windows distribution exe
* OpenSSL loading under Android 6+
* Error on exiting when no connection server started

### Added
* New Plugin: [[CORS Plugin]] to request read permission to other site's content
* New API command: userSetSettings/userGetSettings to store site's settings in users.json
* Avoid file download if the file size does not match with the requested one
* Javascript and wrapper less file accessing using /raw/ prefix
* --silent command line option to disable logging to stdout

### Changed
* Better error reporting on sign/verification errors
* More test for sign and verification process
* Update to OpenSSL v1.0.21
* Limit compressed files to 6MB to avoid zip/tar.gz bomb
* Allow space, [], () characters in filenames
* Disable cross-site resource loading to improve privacy
* Download directly accessed Pdf/Svg/Swf files instead of displaying them to avoid wrapper escape using in JS in SVG file.
* Disallow potentially unsafe regular expressions to avoid ReDoS

## 0.5.6
*June 18, 2017*

### Fixed
* Proxy bypass during source upgrade
* XSS vulnerability using DNS rebinding
* Opened port checking
* Standalone update.py argument parsing
* uPnP crash on startup
* CoffeeScript 1.12.6 compatibility
* Multi value argument parsing
* Database error when running from directory that contains special characters
* Site lock violation logging

### Added
* Callback for certSelect API command
* More compact list formatting in json

### Changed
* Removed obsolete auth_key_sha512 and signature format
* Improved Spanish translation

## 0.5.5
*May 22, 2017*
* Site blacklist option at deletion
* Update cloned sites source code
* New priority algorithm for faster site content display
* Outgoing socket bind option

## 0.5.4
*April 18, 2017*
* Major [[Tor]]: always mode improvements
* Important security fixes
* Updated dependencies
* Better content distribution

## 0.5.3
*March 15, 2017*
* Tar.gz and zip compressed static content support

## 0.5.2
*February 24, 2017*
* User mute

## 0.5.1
*February 8, 2017*
* Multi-language interface and site translate support

## 0.5.0
*November 18, 2016*
* Limit and manage [[Optional Files]]
* API command to sign up/download/delete optional files

## 0.4.1
*September 6, 2016*
* Dramatically speedup startup times
* Reduce memory usage

## 0.4.0
*September 5, 2016*
* Merger sites
* User file archiving
* Allow to store custom fields in json table

## 0.3.7
*August 10, 2016*
* Patch command to reduce bandwidth usage by transfer only the changed lines
* Other cpu/memory optimizations

## 0.3.6
*April 20, 2016*
* New ZeroHello
* NewsFeed function
* Security fixes

## 0.3.5
*February 1, 2016*
* Full [[Tor]] support with .onion hidden services
* Bootstrap using ZeroNet protocol
* Fix Gevent 1.0.2 compatibility

## 0.3.4
*January 4, 2016*
* AES, ECIES API function support
* PushState and ReplaceState url manipulation
* Multiuser localstorage

# ZeroMedium | [[Social Network]]

[ZeroMedium](/ZeroMedium.bit) is a social network created by [[Krixano]] as a clone/alternative to [Medium.com](https://www.medium.com) for ZeroNet. It was first released on October 1st, 2017 An initial version of inline markdown support was released on October 12th, 2017. The November part 1 (aka 17-11A) update added the ability to add Images via [[Optional Files]] support. ZeroMedium was added to [[Git Center]] on November 2nd, 2017.

The bit domain was registered by lingdu.

# ZeroNet Dev Center

[ZeroNet Dev Center](/14pM9huTYzJdyQyHRj6v2kfhMe8DrxwpGt) is [[Krixano]]'s second zite created to provide more resources for learning how to develop for [[ZeroNet]]. It currently features a few tutorials written by three different people in total, including [[Lola]], [[Glightstar]], and Krixano himself, as well as a place, similar to Stack Overflow, where you can ask development questions.

# Important Zites

[Important Zites](/15Pf9VVuDT8NSWj1qUBh4V89yPmrmzRw6a), created by [[Krixano]], was a zite that listed the most important and useful zites by category. It was created before [[ZeroSites]]. You were able to select a category from a menu on the side to filter out the list. Later, a search feature was added with the ability to open the first zite listed in a new tab when you press Enter. Eventually, Krixano added the ability to request zites be added or removed. After ZeroSites was released, the zite was rarely updated.

# ZeroWiki

[ZeroWiki](/138R53t3ZW7KDfSfxVpWUsMXgwUnsDNXLP) was the very first Wiki for ZeroNet.

On November 10th, 2017 [[Krixano]] began work on a clone with better organization and more information.

# ZeroUp | [[File Sharing]]

[ZeroUp](/1uPLoaDwKzP6MCGoVzw48r4pxawRBdmQc) is a zite created by Nofish to demo the [[Big Files]] feature. It was first published when Big Files was released, on October 5th, 2017. Soon after Big Files and ZeroUp was released, Kopy Kate Big was also released as a Big File version of Kopy Kate, a video sharing platform.

# Zites

A Zite is a [[ZeroNet]] [[website]]. Zites have the notable difference of being entirely [[decentralized]] and work even if the visitor is offline. Zites are designed to be entirely [[open source]] and freely shared. Zite owners can also make their site [[cloneable]]. This ensures content is not censored and cannot be forcefully taken down.

However, due to how the site is distributed and viewed, sites must be entirely contained within local [[HTML]] and [[JavaScript]] files. Information for the site can be stored in an [[SQLite]] database or in [[JSON]] files.

Zites require the private key generated with the address in order to be edited or published. Users of the zite have a subdirectory they may edit within the zite's file structure.

[KEEP THIS?]
[ZeroTuto](/1Jtjb5CU9aod4jtz8hF5NPPqFKofRSsb4x), is a great resource for creating zites.

Various attempts have been made to index and search the hundreds of zites that have been created. [[Search engine|Search engines]] like [[Kaffiene]] or [[ZeroSearch]] allow searching through hand-crafted indexes using key terms. While other zites, like [[0list]] or [[ZeroCentral]], allow user submissions to generate a list.

# bigcat.tk | [[ZeroNet Proxies]]

[bigcat.tk](https://www.bigcat.tk) is a [[zeronet-proxies|ZeroNet Proxy]] created by [[KopyJane]]. During November 2017, KopyJane experimented with ad networks in order to monetize the proxy. The proxy currently uses [[CoinHive]] for monetization, falling back on an Ad banner, shown at the top, if the permission to run CoinHive in the background was declined.

# ZeroMe | [[Social Network]]
[ZeroMe](/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit) is the social network for [[ZeroNet]], made by [[Nofish]]. Users can share texts and photos, as well as comment on posts of other profiles. Users can also follow other users and like posts.

Was later forked by [[Mkg20001]] into [[zerome-reloaded|ZeroMe Beta]], later renamed to ZeroMe Reloaded, which added features such as background image/color on user profile pages. A pull request was made to integrate these changes into the official ZeroMe zite. However, Nofish rejected the request in preference of keeping ZeroMe simple. Later, ZeroMe Beta was forked by Plasmmer, which resulted in another zite, called [[ZeroMe Alpha]]. Eventually, ZeroMe Beta was renamed to ZeroMe Reloaded.

To use [[zerome|ZeroMe]] you need to choose a [[hubs|hub]].

# Plasmmer | [[Well-Known Developers]]

Plasmmer was one-half of the ZeroNeards organization. He forked [[Kaffiene]] into [[Snifferdog]] and [[zerome-reloaded|ZeroMe Beta]], later renamed to ZeroMe Reloaded, into [[ZeroMe Alpha]].

It currently features a few tutorials written by three different people in total, including Krixano himself, as well as a place, similar to Stack Overflow, where you can ask development questions.

# Zites

A Zite is a [[ZeroNet]] [[website]]. Zites have the notable difference of being entirely [[decentralized]] and work even if the visitor is offline. Zites are designed to be entirely [[open source]] and freely shared. Zite owners can also make their site [[cloneable]]. This ensures content is not censored and cannot be forcefully taken down.

However, due to how the site is distributed and viewed, sites must be entirely contained within local [[HTML]] and [[JavaScript]] files. Information for the site can be stored in an [[SQLite]] database or in [[JSON]] files.

Zites require the private key generated with the address in order to be edited or published. Users of the zite have a subdirectory they may edit within the zite's file structure.

[KEEP THIS?]
[ZeroTuto](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Jtjb5CU9aod4jtz8hF5NPPqFKofRSsb4x/), is a great resource for creating zites.

Various attempts have been made to index and search the hundreds of zites that have been created. [[Search engine|Search engines]] like [[Kaffiene]] or [[ZeroSearch]] allow searching through hand-crafted indexes using key terms. While other zites, like [[0list]] or [[ZeroCentral]], allow user submissions to generate a list.

# Wiki help

To help you navigate this wiki there is a Home and Index button in every page. Feel free to click any link you see in the texts too, they will take you to magic places.

Blue links will take you to existing pages which already have content and intersting things for you to read. On the other hand, red links will lead you to pages that do not exist yet, you will be able to add content and write some spells to create them.

Most of the pages in this wiki are editable too! just look for the Edit button if you feel the urge to modify what you are reading. This is a collaborative tool for shared knowledge, improve the contents, show your kung-fu, and the community will be grateful forever with dances and songs to remember your feat.

## Text editing

This wiki uses Markdown to format the texts, use it to add titles, to make your text bold or to add links to external resources.

To create links to new or existing pages in this wiki, just use double square brackets around words. The wiki will auto-magically convert it to wiki-links. It will also detect if the page already exists and use the corresponding color to display the link.

# Important Zites

[Important Zites](http://127.0.0.1:43110/15Pf9VVuDT8NSWj1qUBh4V89yPmrmzRw6a), created by [[Krixano]], was a zite that listed the most important and useful zites by category. It was created before [[ZeroSites]]. You were able to select a category from a menu on the side to filter out the list. Later, a search feature was added with the ability to open the first zite listed in a new tab when you press Enter. Eventually, Krixano added the ability to request zites be added or removed. After ZeroSites was released, the zite was rarely updated.

# Big Files | [[ZeroNet Plugins]]

Big Files was created in order to share bigger files (20MB to many GBs) within ZeroNet. The files are downloaded in the background and streamed to your computer. This allows you to, for example, watch a video while the video is downloading. [[ZeroUp]] was released at the same time as this plugin to demo Big Files. Later, [[KopyKate Big]] was released as another version of [[Kopy Kate]] with Big Files support.

# ZeroUp | [[File Sharing]]

[ZeroUp](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1uPLoaDwKzP6MCGoVzw48r4pxawRBdmQc) is a zite created by Nofish to demo the [[Big Files]] feature. It was first published when Big Files was released, on October 5th, 2017. Soon after Big Files and ZeroUp was released, Kopy Kate Big was also released as a Big File version of Kopy Kate, a video sharing platform.

# Search Engine

* [[Zirch]]
* [[EulerFinder]]
* [[Snifferdog]]
* [[RVRE]] (previously bwoi)
* [[Kaffiene]] - Outdated
* [[ZeroSearch]]
